textset.title: EICAS
textset.para: The Engine Indication and Crew Alerting System (EICAS) provides displays of engine parameters, crew alerts of non-normal conditions, systems status and maintenance data. EICAS messages are divided into the following categories:
WARNING — Red message and light, Master Warning light illuminates, Master Warning Aural sounds, immediate crew action required.
CAUTION — Amber message and light, Master Caution light illuminates, Master Caution Aural sounds, immediate crew awareness and future crew action required.
ADVISORY — Amber message and light, crew awareness and possible future crew action required.
STATUS — White message displayed on EICAS Status page, provides readiness for dispatch information which require crew awareness, possible crew action and/or MEL relief prior to takeoff.
MAINTENANCE — White message displayed on ECS/MSG page of EICAS, for use of maintenance personnel.
EEC MAINTENANCE — White message displayed on EPCS page, Pratt & Whitney engine-related maintenance only.

All messages of status level or higher affect airplane dispatchability and conditions causing their appearance must be corrected prior to flight or the Minimum Equipment List (MEL) consulted to determine possible dispatch relief.
Status messages indicate equipment faults which affect dispatchability but are not necessarily identified by higher category (Alert) EICAS messages.
Maintenance messages do not prohibit dispatch but must be corrected in accordance with United Parcel Service's approved maintenance program.

The EICAS Message List which follows contains those messages which are in the Warning, Caution, Advisory or Status categories. This section is provided as a "Quick Reference" between EICAS messages and Minimum Equipment List (MEL) items which may provide dispatch relief.

Normal crew procedures require checking status messages during cockpit preparation to determine airplane dispatchability. CAUTION and ADVISORY messages do not require crew action up to this time because they reflect systems not yet configured for flight and should disappear as a result of crew action during flight deck preparation. WARNING messages should be dealt with immediately whenever they are displayed.

Any message adversely affecting safe continuation of the flight or requiring crew attention, will appear as an EICAS alert message (WARNING, CAUTION or ADVISORY). From engine start until shutdown at the completion of flight, EICAS alert messages are the primary means of alerting the flight crews to non-normal conditions or improper configuration. After engine start and prior to takeoff, any alert message requires accomplishment of the appropriate non-normal procedure by the crew. Upon completion of the non-normal procedure and prior to takeoff, consult the MEL to determine if relief is available. Status messages observed prior to takeoff may require crew action. Attempt to clear status message, if unable, refer to the MEL to determine appropriate action. There are no safety issues or QRH procedures associated with an inflight status message. Do not use the MEL inflight. Make a logbook entry upon arrival at the scheduled destination.

Dispatch capability with an invalid EICAS message depends on the message level. Dispatch with invalid status level messages is allowed by MEL item 31-61-4, provided that either the associated equipment is verified to operate normally or the dispatch deviations for the associated equipment are observed. However, there is no specific item in the MEL for dispatch with invalid Alert level (Warning, Caution, or Advisory) messages, since they are required for inflight crew awareness or action as described at the beginning of Section 1. Thus, if an Alert message is displayed, dispatch is allowed only if there is MEL relief for the associated equipment fault or failure, and the applicable dispatch deviations are applied. If system deactivation procedures result in an associated Alert message remaining OFF, dispatch may be acceptable if no inflight alert is needed for the deactivated equipment. In most cases, appropriate placards or flight log entries provide sufficient crew awareness.

The MEL lists the items of airplane equipment that may be inoperative, and the conditions under which dispatch is allowed. The purpose of the Cross-Reference List is to relate an EICAS message indicating an equipment fault or failure to the MEL item(s) that allows dispatch with the condition indicated by the message. It is intended to assist operators in quickly identifying the proper MEL items to consult to determine airplane dispatchability. The list includes the message, a description of the condition(s) that result in message display, message level, and possible MEL cross reference as follows:

xx-xx-xx — The indicated MEL item should be consulted for possible dispatch when the associated message is displayed. If the message description indicates more than one possible equipment fault, multiple MEL items may be listed. In such cases, additional system troubleshooting may be required to determine the equipment fault(s) that are present.
No Takeoff — Takeoff is not allowed unless the message is invalid. In such cases, MEL item 31-61-4 may be used to dispatch.
Not Applicable — The message does not necessarily indicate a system fault or failure. Dispatch is allowed provided appropriate crew procedures are followed.

entry.para: Fwd and E/E Access doors unlatched.
Aft cabin supply duct temperature excessive or zone temperature forward cabin channel failure or switched off.
Aft cargo detector loop 1 unsatisfactory test or smoke detected.
Aft cargo detector loop 2 unsatisfactory test or smoke detected.
Aft cargo door not closed and locked.
Smoke in aft equipment cooling exhaust duct.
Aft equipment exhaust fan 1 or 2 failure.
Aft switch/valve disagree - provisions for dual fuel cross feed - inhibited by FUEL CROSSFEED message.
System 1 and system 2 air/ground logic disagree – main gear tilt.
Deviation of 300 feet from selected altitude.
Antiskid system detects fault in alternate system.
Antiskid system detects fault in normal system (or alternate if selected) .
APU bleed valve not in commanded position.
APU door disagrees with selected position.
APU fire loop 1 fire or fault output.
APU fire loop 2 fire or fault output.
APU fuel valve disagrees with commanded position.
APU generator auxiliary power breaker open with APU running and external power contactor open or APU generator control switch off.
APU oil quantity low level switch detects 30 hours run time remaining with APU running.
Loss of ADC, FMC, stab. trim, ILS or RA inputs to active autopilot.
Manual or automatic disengagement of autothrottle or failure to remove power from autothrottle servo.
Bleed isolation valve not in commanded position.
Hydraulic brake pressure supplied by accumulator only.
Center hydraulic flight control valves closed.
Center electrical pump 1 output pressure low.
Center electrical pump 2 output pressure low.
Center hydraulic reservoir pressure low with both engines running.
Center hydraulic pressure low with both engine running.
Center Inertial Reference System DC failure.
Center Inertial Reference System on DC Power.
Loss of automatic pressurization controllers 1 and 2 or manual selected.
Captain’s instrument bus transferred with left main bus still powered.
Captain’s main pitot heat power or continuity loss or incorrect power level.
Two or more doors not closed and locked.
Loss of datalink system due to ACARS MU failure.
Duct leak/wheel well fire system logic card self detected fault.
EICAS display select control panel fault.
Computer fault causing an engine parameter disagreement code (between left and right EICAS computers) or a computer fault effecting the caution alerting function.
EICAS upper or lower pilots display unit failed, off, or blank due to computer fault.
Signal consolidation card failure in the P51 card file bite detected fault.
Center elevator hydraulic system pressure reducer valve senses high or low pressure.
Left elevator hydraulic system pressure reducer valve senses high or low pressure.
Right elevator hydraulic system pressure reducer valve senses high or low pressure.
Emergency light switch in OFF or ON position.

Two or more EEC channels inoperative on the ground with both engines running or stator vane position cross check failure, or thrust reverser position sensor cross check failure, or EEC detected air data failure condition.
One or more equipment cooling supply fans failed in either the forward or aft blow through system.
Low flow detected in forward, flight deck, or aft cooling ducts on the ground.
One or more low flow sensor(s) failed test.
Equipment cooling system automatic self-test not performed or not completed.
Both forward or both aft supply fans not running or left recirculation fan failed and overboard exhaust valve not open after 10 seconds.
Forward equipment smoke detection system failed automatic test.
First Officer’s instrument bus transferred with right main bus still powered.
First Officer’s main pitot heat power or continuity loss or incorrect power level.
Flaps fail to relieve at proper airspeed or fail to recover.
LE and TE flaps not in takeoff position for a takeoff and takeoff thrust selected on either engine.
Flap isolation valve open when uncommanded or failed.
FSEU 1 self-detected loss of normal asymmetry and disagree alerts.
Two or more flight control valves closed.
Flight recorder data acquisition unit fault with both engines running.
Flight recorder off with both engines running.
Flight deck supply duct temperature excessive or zone temperature flight deck channel failure or switched off.
Smoke in duct from flight deck supply fans.
Flight Management System detects one of several high priority FMC messages.
Both center pumps switched off with usable fuel remaining in center tank (Approx. 1,000 lbs.).
Left and right fuel tank quantities differ by approx. 2,000 lbs..
Unknown accuracy in one or more fuel tank quantity indicators or all three quantity indicators, or any FQIS fault coupled with loss of valid digital data.
Fuel quantity indication fault in either channel with valid digital data.
Unknown accuracy in one or two but not three fuel tank quantity indicators with valid digital data.
Forward cabin supply duct temperature excessive, or zone temperature aft cabin channel failure or switched off.
Forward cargo detector loop 1 unsatisfactory test or smoke detected.
Forward cargo detector loop 2 unsatisfactory test or smoke detected.
Forward cargo door not closed and locked.
Smoke in forward equipment cooling supply or exhaust ducts.
Systems 1 and 2 both indicate any gear disagree up or down.
Any landing gear door not closed and locked (systems 1 and 2).
Either throttle at idle and below 800 feet radio altimeter and any gear not down and locked, or landing flaps and any gear not down and locked.
Airspeed difference of 5 kts between the Captain/First Officer air data sources.
Captain’s and First Officer’s EFIS both switched to ALTN on instrument source select switches.
Left AOA probe heat power or continuity loss.
Left auxiliary pitot heat power or continuity loss or incorrect power level.
Duct leak between left engine (or APU) and isolation valve.
Left isolation bus tie automatically or manually locked open.
Left EEC switched off and full forward thrust lever position selected.
Left EICAS computer failed or off.
Valve jammed in one or more left elevator power control units.
Left engine cowl anti-ice valve/switch disagree with engine running.
Left engine Pressure Regulating and Shutoff Valve closed with engine running.

LPT core vent valve is not open when commanded to open (failsafe).

Left HF Datalink failure of the data function of the HF data radio.
Left electrical pump output pressure low.
Left engine driven pump output pressure low with engine running.
Left Hydraulic Reservoir Pressure low with both engines running.
Left hydraulic pressure low with both engines running.
Left engine oil filter pressure differential approaches bypass with oil temperature above 25°C (PW), 10°C (RR).

Left thrust reverser isolation valve fault.

textset.title: PREAMBLE
textset.para: The following is applicable for authorized certificate holders operating under Federal Aviation Regulations (FAR) Parts 121, 125, 129, 135: The FAR require that all equipment installed on an aircraft in compliance with the Airworthiness Standards and the Operating Rules must be operative. However, the Rules also permit the publication of a Minimum Equipment List (MEL) where compliance with certain equipment requirements is not necessary in the interests of safety under all operating conditions. Experience has shown that with the various levels of redundancy designed into aircraft, operation of every system or installed component may not be necessary when the remaining operative equipment can provide an acceptable level of safety. A Master Minimum Equipment List (MMEL) is developed by the FAA, with participation by the aviation industry, to improve aircraft utilization and thereby provide more convenient and economic air transportation for the public. The FAA approved MMEL includes those items of equipment related to airworthiness and operating regulations and other items of equipment which the Administrator finds may be inoperative and yet maintain an acceptable level of safety by appropriate conditions and limitations; it does not contain obviously required items such as wings, flaps, and rudders. The MMEL is the basis for development of individual operator MELs which take into consideration the operator’s particular aircraft equipment configuration and operational conditions. Operator MELs, for administrative control, may include items not contained in the MMEL; however, relief for administrative control items must be approved by the Administrator. An operator’s MEL may differ in format from the MMEL, but cannot be less restrictive than the MMEL. The individual operator’s MEL, when approved and authorized, permits operation of the aircraft with inoperative equipment.

Equipment not required by the operation being conducted and equipment in excess of FAR requirements are included in the MEL with appropriate conditions and limitations. The MEL must not deviate from the Aircraft Flight Manual Limitations, Emergency Procedures or with Airworthiness Directives. It is important to remember that all equipment related to the airworthiness and the operating regulations of the aircraft not listed on the MMEL must be operative.

Suitable conditions and limitations in the form of placards, maintenance procedures, crew operating procedures and other restrictions as necessary are specified in the MEL to ensure that an acceptable level of safety is maintained.

The MEL is intended to permit operation with inoperative items of equipment for a period of time until repairs can be accomplished. It is important that repairs be accomplished at the earliest opportunity. In order to maintain an acceptable level of safety and reliability, the MMEL establishes limitations on the duration of and conditions for operation with inoperative equipment. The MEL provides for release of the aircraft for flight with inoperative equipment. When an item of equipment is discovered to be inoperative, it is reported by making an entry in the Aircraft Maintenance Record/Logbook as prescribed by FAR. The item is then either repaired or may be deferred per the MEL or other approved means acceptable to the Administrator prior to further operation. MEL conditions and limitations do not relieve the operator from determining that the aircraft is in condition for safe operation with items of equipment inoperative.

When these requirements are met, an Airworthiness Release, Aircraft Maintenance Record/Logbook entry, or other approved documentation is issued as prescribed by FAR. Such documentation is required prior to operation with any item of equipment inoperative.

Operators are responsible for exercising the necessary operational control to ensure that an acceptable level of safety is maintained. When operating with multiple inoperative items, the interrelationships between those items and the effect on aircraft operation and crew workload will be considered.
Operators are to establish a controlled and sound repair program including the parts, personnel, facilities, procedures, and schedules to ensure timely repair.
WHEN USING THE MEL, COMPLIANCE WITH THE STATED INTENT OF THE PREAMBLE, DEFINITIONS, AND THE CONDITIONS AND LIMITATIONS SPECIFIED IN THE MEL IS REQUIRED.

numlitem.para: System Definitions.
System numbers are based on the Air Transport Association (ATA) specification number 100 and items are numbered sequentially.

"Item" means the equipment, system, component, or function listed after the MEL number. Repair interval categories (A, B, C, and D) are listed in the Repair Int Category block. Repair intervals are described in definition 22.
"Number Installed" (Installed block) is the number of (quantity) of items normally installed in the aircraft. This number represents the aircraft configuration considered in developing this MEL.

note.para: Where the MMEL shows a variable number installed, the MEL must reflect the actual number installed or an alternate means of configuration control approved by the Administrator.

numlitem.para: "Number Required for Dispatch" (Required block) is the minimum number (quantity) of items required for operation provided the conditions specified in Remarks and Exceptions are met.

note.para: Where the MMEL shows a variable number required for dispatch, the MEL must reflect the actual number required for dispatch or an alternate means of configuration control approved by the Administrator.

numlitem.para: "Remarks and Exceptions" (in the Remarks and Exceptions section) includes a statement either prohibiting or permitting operation with a specific number of items inoperative, provisos (conditions and limitations) for such operation, and appropriate notes.

References given in the Remarks and Exceptions section are to bring attention to certain interrelationships between the subject item and other MEL items or DMP and/or AOM material. These references are intended to assist with compliance, but do not relieve the operator of the responsibility for determining such inter-relationships as stated in the Preamble.
A vertical bar (change bar) in the margin indicates a change or addition in the adjacent text for the current revision of that item only. The change bar is dropped at the next MMEL revision.

"Airplane Flight Manual" (AFM) is the document required for type certification and approved by the responsible FAA Aircraft Certification Office. The FAA approved AFM for the specific aircraft is listed on the applicable Type Certificate Data Sheet.
Not applicable.
Each inoperative item must be placarded to inform and remind the crewmembers and maintenance personnel of the equipment condition.

note.para: To the extent practical, placards should be located adjacent to the control or indicator for the item affected; however, unless otherwise specified, placard wording and location will be determined by the operator.

numlitem.para: Dash "–" Symbol in the installed block indicates a variable number (quantity) of the item installed.
"Deleted" after a sequence number indicates the item was previously listed but is now required to be operative if installed in the aircraft.
"ER" – As used in MMELs, "ER" refers to Extended Operations (ETOPS) of an aircraft with operational approval to conduct ETOPS in accordance with the applicable regulations.

note.para: UPS does not operate the B757 aircraft on ER operations; therefore, it must remain within 60 minutes of a suitable airport.

numlitem.para: "Federal Aviation Regulations" (FAR) – the applicable portions of the Federal Aviation Act and Federal Aviation Regulations.
"Flight Day" – a 24 hour period (from midnight to midnight) SDF local time, as established by UPS, during which at least one flight is initiated for the affected aircraft.
"Icing Conditions" – an atmospheric environment that may cause ice to form on the aircraft (structural) or in the engine(s) (induction).
Alphabetical symbol (in the Remarks and Exceptions section) indicates a provisio (condition or limitation) that must be complied with for operation with the listed item inoperative.

"Inoperative" – any time a system and/or component malfunctions to the extent that it does not accomplish its intended purpose and/or is not consistently functioning within its designed operating limit(s) or tolerance(s). If an item of equipment is deferred or any proviso indicates an item of equipment is inoperative or considered to be inoperative, that equipment shall not be used during flight unless authorized by the MEL.

Notes: – (In the Remarks and Exceptions section) provides additional information for crewmember or maintenance consideration. Notes are to identify applicable material which are intended to assist with compliance, but do not relieve the operator of the responsibility for compliance with all applicable requirements. Notes are not a part of the provisos.

Inoperative components of an inoperative system: Inoperative items which are components of a system which is inoperative are usually considered components directly associated with and having no other function than to support that system. (Warning/caution systems associated with the inoperative system must be operative unless relief is specifically authorized per the MMEL).

"(M)" symbol (in the Remarks and Exceptions section) indicates a requirement for a specific maintenance procedure which must be accomplished prior to operation with the listed item inoperative. Normally these procedures are accomplished by maintenance personnel; however, other personnel may be qualified and authorized to perform certain functions. Procedures requiring specialized knowledge or skill, or requiring the use of tools or test equipment should be accomplished by maintenance personnel. The satisfactory accomplishment of all maintenance procedures, regardless of who performs them, is the responsibility of the operator. Appropriate procedures are required to be published as part of the operator's manual or MEL.

"(O)“ symbol (in the Remarks and Exceptions section) indicates a requirement for a specific operations procedure which must be accomplished in planning for and/or operating with the listed item inoperative. Normally these procedures are accomplished by the flight crew; however, other personnel may be qualified and authorized to perform certain functions. The satisfactory accomplishment of all procedures, regardless of who performs them, is the responsibility of the operator. Appropriate procedures are required to be published as part of the operator's manual or MEL.

note.para: The (M) and (O) symbols are required in the operator's MEL unless otherwise authorized by the Administrator.

numlitem.para: "Deactivated" and "Secured" – means that the specified component must be put into an acceptable condition for safe flight. An acceptable method of securing or deactivating will be listed in the Operations Procedure section, Maintenance Procedure section, or corresponding Dispatch Maintenance Procedure.
Visual Flight Rules (VFR) is as defined in FAR Part 91. This precludes a pilot from filing an IFR flight plan.

"Visual Meteorological Conditions" (VMC) – the atmospheric environment is such that would allow a flight to proceed under the visual flight rules applicable to the flight. This does not preclude operating under Instrument Flight Rules.
"Visible Moisture" – an atmospheric environment containing water in any form that can be seen in natural or artificial light, for example; clouds, fog, rain, sleet, hail, or snow.
"Passenger Convenience Items" – Deleted see NEF #30.

Repair Intervals: (Repair Int Category block) All MEL users must effect repairs of inoperative systems or components, deferred in accordance with the MEL, at or prior to the repair times established by the following letter designators:

note.para: It is permissible to dispatch an aircraft provided the time limitation has not expired at the time of blockout.

numlitem.para: Category A. Items in this category shall be repaired within the time interval specified in the remarks section of the operator's approved MEL. For time intervals specified in "flight days," the day the malfunction was recorded in the aircraft maintenance record/logbook is excluded. For all other time intervals (flights, flight legs, cycles, hours, etc.,), repair tracking begins at the point when the malfunction is deferred in accordance with the operator's approved MEL.

Category B. Items in this category shall be repaired within three (3) consecutive calendar days (72 hours), excluding the day the malfunction was recorded in the aircraft maintenance record/logbook. For example, if it were recorded at 10 a.m. on January 26th, the three day interval would begin at midnight the 26th and end at midnight the 29th. All time will be based on SDF local time.

Category C. Items in this category shall be repaired within ten (10) consecutive calendar days (240 hours), excluding the day the malfunction was recorded in the aircraft maintenance record/logbook. For example, if it were recorded at 10 am. on January 26th, the 10 day interval would begin at midnight the 26th and end at midnight February 5th. All time will be based on SDF local time.

Category D. Items in this category shall be repaired within one hundred and twenty (120) consecutive calendar days (2880 hours), excluding the day the malfunction was recorded in the aircraft maintenance log and/or record. The letter designators are inserted adjacent to the Installed block.

An operator who has the authorization to use an MEL also has the authority to approve extensions to the maximum repair interval for category B and C items provided the responsible Flight Standards District Office (FSDO) is notified within 24 hours of the MEL extension. The operator is not authorized to extend A and D items in the MEL. Misuse of the MEL extension authority may result in the operators OpSpecs/Mspecs being amended by removing the authority for the operator to use the MEL extension authority and/or use an MEL.

"Electronic fault alerting system" – Boeing airplanes equipped with Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting Systems (EICAS), provide different priority levels of system messages (WARNING, CAUTION, ADVISORY, STATUS and MAINTENANCE). Any messages that affect airplane dispatch status will be displayed at a STATUS message level or higher. The absence of an EICAS STATUS or higher level (WARNING, CAUTION, ADVISORY) indicates that the system/component is operating within its approved operating limits or tolerances.

System conditions that result only in a maintenance level message, i.e. no correlation with a higher level EICAS message, do not affect dispatch and do not require action other than as addressed within an operators standard maintenance program.

"Administrative control item" means an item listed by the operator in the MEL for tracking and informational purposes. It may be added to an operator’s MEL by approval of the Principal Operations Inspector provided no relief is granted, or provided conditions and limitations are contained in an approved document (i.e., Structural Repair Manual, airworthiness directive, etc.). If relief other than that granted by an approved document is sought for an administrative control item, a request must be submitted to the Administrator. If the request results in review and approval by the FOEB, the item becomes an MMEL item rather than an administrative control item.
Not applicable.
"Excess items" means those items that have been installed that are redundant to the requirements of the FARs.

"Day of Discovery" – the calendar day an equipment/instrument malfunction was recorded in the aircraft maintenance logbook and or record. This day is excluded from the calendar days or flight days specified in the MEL for the repair of an inoperative item of equipment. This provision is applicable to all MEL items, i.e., categories "A, B, C, and D".

"Considered Inoperative", as used in the provisos means that item must be treated for dispatch, taxi and flight purposes as though it were inoperative. The item shall not be used or operated until the original deferred item is repaired. Additional actions include: documenting the item on the dispatch release (if applicable), placarding, and complying with all remarks, exceptions, and related MMEL provisions, including any (M) and (O) procedures and observing the repair category.

"Is not used" in the provisos, remarks or exceptions for an MMEL item may specify that another item relieved in the MMEL "is not used". In such cases, crewmembers should not activate, actuate, or otherwise utilize that component or system under normal operations. It is not necessary for the operators to accomplish the (M) procedures associated with the item. However, operational requirements must be complied with, and an additional placard must be affixed, to the extent practical, adjacent to the control or indicator for the item that is not used to inform crewmembers that a component or system is not to be used under normal operations.

Nonessential equipment and furnishings (NEF) are those items installed on the aircraft as part of the original type certification, supplemental type certificate, or other form of alteration that have no effect on the safe operation of flight and would not be required by the applicable certification rules or operational rules. They are those items that if inoperative, damaged or missing have no effect on the aircraft's ability to be operated safely under all operational conditions. These nonessential items may be installed in areas including, but not limited to, the passenger compartment, flight deck area, service areas, cargo areas, crew rest areas, lavatories, and galley areas. NEF items are not items already identified in the MEL or CDL of the applicable aircraft. They do not include items that are functionally required to meet the certification rule or for compliance with any operational rule. Operator's NEF process shall not provide for deferral of items within serviceable limits identified in the manufacturer's maintenance manual or operator's approved maintenance program such as wear limits, fuel/hydraulic leak rates, oil consumption, etc. Cosmetic items that are fully serviceable but worn or soiled may be deferred under an operator's NEF process.
As used in MMELs, Heavy Maintenance Visit (HMV) is a scheduled C-check/D-check or airworthiness maintenance program inspection where the aircraft is scheduled to be out of service for 4 or more days.
"Affected" – refers to the subject item of equipment (component, system or function) listed in the Item Title.
"Associated" – refers to a related component, system or function other than the subject one.
Class E Cargo – all UPS B-757 aircraft are in a Class E Cargo configuration.

Effectivity – Aircraft Registration Numbers listed following the MEL Title indicate the effectivity which applies to an MEL item number. These effectivities are as accurate and up–to–date as possible as of the publication revision date. However, if an aircraft registration number does not appear following the MEL Title, but physical inspection of the aircraft indicates an item is installed, relief may be taken and the item deferred provided the number of items required for dispatch are operational and the appropriate procedures are accomplished.

note.para: Some items listed in the Minimum Equipment List reference a corresponding maintenance procedure in the Dispatch Maintenance Procedures section. It is the responsibility of maintenance personnel to ensure that applicable DMP procedures are accomplished.

numlitem.para: "Instrument Meteorological Conditions" (IMC) – Meteorological conditions expressed in terms of visibility distance from cloud, and ceiling less than the minimums specified for visual meteorological conditions.
"Not Applicable" (in the Title section) – Refers to equipment or subcomponents of a system which are no longer installed or part of the configuration or UPS is not taking relief.
References in this document to the Airplane Operations Manual (AOM) or Airport Analysis Manual (AAM) replace the references in the FAA Master Minimum Equipment List to Airplane Flight Manual (AFM).
"Repair" – Means such maintenance action, including replacement, as necessary to restore an inoperative item to an operative condition.
"Sub–System" – A major functional portion of a system which contributes to operational completeness of the system.
"System" – A combination of interrelated items arranged to perform a specific function.
"Time In Service" – The time from the moment an aircraft leaves the surface of the earth until it touches it at the next point of landing (as defined in FAR Part l).

"Operations Procedure" – This section includes specific (O) operations procedures called for in the Remarks or Exception section, which must be accomplished in planning for and/or operating with the listed item inoperative. (Refer to the (O) definition, number 16 in this chapter.)
Operative – The available functions meet the intended purpose required to complete the flight.

"Maintenance Procedure" – When a (M) Maintenance Procedure is required, a reference will display ("Accomplish Dispatch Maintenance Procedure XX-XX-X") in the Maintenance Procedure section of the MEL. This reference links the procedure to a specific DMP. However, when a (M) Maintenance Procedure is NOT required, the Maintenance Procedure section in the MEL may include Notes, Downgrade statements and CAT boxes.

"Limitations/Performance Penalties" – This section includes specific limitations or performance penalties that must be complied with during flight planning, prior to departure, en route or during approach and landing. Compliance with the limitations in this section do not relieve the user from complying with the Repair Int Category block, Required block, Remarks and Exceptions section, Operations Procedure section, and Maintenance Procedure section.
Reduced Vertical Separation Minimums (RVSM) – A program to permit operations of 1000 feet vertical separation.
"Blockout" – The time the aircraft begins movement for the purpose of takeoff either by pushback, tow or under its own power.

Required Navigation Performance Capability (RNP) is a statement of navigation performance necessary for operation within a defined airspace. RNP-10 is defined in FAA order 8400.12 series and European Basic Area Navigation (BRNAV/RNP-5) in Advisory Circular #90-96 series.

Required Navigation Performance Capability is a standard for continuing airworthiness based on a more stringent separation parameter to be implemented as part of a worldwide ICAO effort to implement the Future Air Navigation Systems (FANS), Communication/Navigation/Surveillance (CNS) and Air Traffic Management (ATM) concept. Currently, a 50 nautical mile lateral separation on the North Pacific (NOPAC) and selected Central Pacific (CEPAC) routes are based on RNP-10 criteria. This performance capability is similar to existing minimum navigation performance specifications (MNPS) over the North Atlantic. At least two Long Range Navigation systems should be operational at oceanic entry points. MNPS or RNP-5 navigation accuracy BRNAV requirements are met where RNP-10 is authorized.
"Takeoff" - The act of beginning flight in which an aircraft is accelerated from a state of rest to that of flight.

UPS Special Operations Airports – A more restrictive definition applied to certain airports listed in FAR 121.445 and other airports selected by UPS due to arrival/departure requirements, local topography and/or uniqueness of localized weather phenomena. The following airports are designated as UPS Special Operations Airports:

UPS Lettered Revision (Red Revision) – is an interim revision that is designated by a letter, with the intent of addressing Airworthiness Directives and/or safety of flight issues that impact the MEL/DMP. Additionally, an Engineering Order (EO) will be issued to supersede the affected DMP until the UPS Lettered Revision is published.
"Ballast Weights" – Ballast is any weight added to the aircraft for the purpose of CG control. It will be loaded on/in a ULD and loaded uniformly and with barrier nets in place.

note.para: Materials loaded on/in a ULD for use as ballast during flight, must not consist of any combustible, flammable or otherwise hazardous material. The weight of ballast materials, such as concrete blocks, metal plates, and sand bags must be distributed evenly across the floor of the ULD and secured to prevent shifting during flight.

textgrp.title: General
textgrp.para: Maintenance personnel shall perform maintenance on the maintenance significant and/or flight operations significant system(s)/component(s) listed, per one of the following procedures, as applicable.

numlitem.para: Qualified Maintenance Personnel Procedures
Non-Qualified Personnel Procedures

textgrp.title: Flight Operations Significant Cat 2/3 Systems/Components
textgrp.para: Component(s)/System(s) which do not possess complex operational, aircraft system interface, and performance degradation characteristics, but are essential for CAT 2/3 operations.
